title: rito, what program(s) do you guys use to make your amazing splash arts?
body:
I'm looking to get into digital art and was wondering what kinds of programs do they use. I reckon it's done in photoshop? if so which version? and do they use other programs for final touches and polishing? 

thanks in advance :^)

replies.body:
Hi Twiskies!  I'm an illustrator on the Champions team.  First thank you for your kind words, and you ask a good question!

Its pretty standard to use Adobe Photoshop - I use CC 2016, at home and at work, with a Wacom tablet.  I also think a program called PureRef is really helpful for organizing reference materials.  There are dozens if not hundreds of reference images for each splash - from pose and character model to materials and lighting.  Sometimes I like to sketch on my iPad with Autodesk Sketchbook Pro.

When it comes to polishing, Photoshop is just too powerful to use anything else.  I think the 'magic' comes from studying things like film, movies and environments and replicating believable effects like depth of field, atmosphere, dust motes, vfx, etc.  It's not dissimilar to photo processing in Photoshop.  Check out some youtube videos about really cool things like the color lookup and selective color tools.

Hope that helps! :)

I also commented on this with some advice, lol. First comment. 

I still recommend Manga Studio (Clip Studio). But that's my personal preference. 
An artist I really admire does most of her work (sketches, colours) in Manga Studio and adds small finishing touches in Photoshop if needed.
Industry standard is usually Photoshop, but it depends on what company you work for or if you're working freelance.

Biggest thing is that Manga Studio and Paint Tool Sai are one-time purchases, whereas Photoshop is subscription-based.
I use Clip Studio Paint, it is very efficient and powerful.
Photoshop is actually not the best software for outright painting, but it is certainly sufficient has has a lot of resources.
